Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases occurring during high temperatures indicate reactive compensation for heat-driven dryness
Description: When the system boosts irrigation in response to weather logs during heat spikes, it reflects drying pressure from elevated temperatures.
short rationale: Heat-driven boosts; operational response with low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during high humidity indicate effective recognition of low evaporative demand
Description: Cutting irrigation when humidity is high shows the system correctly anticipates reduced moisture loss.
short rationale: High humidity reductions; operational cue, minimal privacy exposure.

Inference: Weather-driven irrigation increases during low humidity reflect accurate detection of atmospheric dryness
Description: The system adds more water when humidity drops because dry air accelerates evaporation.
short rationale: Dry-air increases; operational pattern only.

Inference: Weather-driven irrigation reductions during cooling periods show alignment with natural temperature-driven moisture savings
Description: Cool temperatures slow evaporation, making irrigation reductions appropriate.
short rationale: Cooling-linked cuts; operational trend, low risk.

Inference: Frequent weather-based increases paired with rising average temperatures indicate sustained dry-season conditions
Description: Weather adjustments and heat both trend upward, signaling a prolonged drying period.
short rationale: Dry-season pattern; operational/climate signal.

Inference: Weather-based reductions paired with decreasing temperatures indicate seasonal transition into cooler, wetter conditions
Description: The system reduces watering as temperature falls, reflecting lower natural demand.
short rationale: Seasonal cooling cuts; operational trend only.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases that occur only during low humidity periods indicate humidity is a major driver of weather logic
Description: The system likely prioritizes atmospheric dryness when determining irrigation needs.
short rationale: Humidity-driven boosts; operational logic insight, low risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions occurring even during low temperatures suggest overriding rainfall or moisture signals
Description: Irrigation cuts despite low temperature imply that weather-based rainfall detection takes priority over temperature conditions.
short rationale: Rain/moisture overrides temp; operational context.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during both high temperature and high humidity indicate extreme environmental moisture stress
Description: Hot and humid conditions can create plant stress, and the system may compensate with more watering.
short rationale: Hot/humid stress boosts; operational signal only.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during high temperature and high humidity suggest rainfall input is strong enough to offset heat stress
Description: Even though heat might suggest watering, rainfall-based reductions prevail.
short rationale: Rain offsets heat; operational logic, low privacy impact.

Inference: Weather-based adjustments clustering during peak temperature periods indicate strong temperature sensitivity in weather-processing logic
Description: More adjustments occur when temperatures are highest, reflecting heat-driven dryness behavior.
short rationale: Timing of adjustments at heat peaks exposes logic weighting/schedule behavior.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases with weak temperature or humidity variation indicate forecast-driven or predictive logic
Description: The system may react to predicted conditions rather than measured environmental changes.
short rationale: Boosts without measured change reveal forecast/predictive control.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during stable temperature and humidity suggest rainfall signals independent of environmental conditions
Description: If climate readings are stable but irrigation is still reduced, rainfall is likely occurring.
short rationale: Rain-driven cuts with stable climate; operational context only.

Inference: Lack of weather-driven increases during low humidity periods suggests conservative watering logic
Description: The system may avoid boosting irrigation unless multiple dryness indicators align.
short rationale: Conservative logic overrides dryness; configuration/behavior exposure.

Inference: Weather-driven increases during temperature plateaus but humidity declines indicate humidity is the dominant trigger
Description: Humidity changes alone can cause irrigation boosts even when temperature remains constant.
short rationale: Humidity dominates decisions; operational weighting only.

Inference: Weather-driven reductions during humidity increases but high temperatures indicate humidity outweighs heat signals in decision-making
Description: The system reduces watering despite heat because humidity suggests reduced evaporation.
short rationale: Humidity outweighs heat; operational weighting.

Inference: High humidity paired with many weather-based irrigation reductions indicates rainfall-heavy climate periods
Description: Humidity rises often due to precipitation, triggering reduced irrigation needs.
short rationale: Rain-heavy periods drive cuts; operational/climate signal.

Inference: Low humidity paired with many weather-based irrigation increases indicates drought-like conditions
Description: Dry air signals a deficit in natural moisture that the system attempts to compensate for.
short rationale: Drought-like dryness drives boosts; operational trend only.

Inference: Weather-driven irrigation increases that correspond tightly with falling humidity indicate precise atmospheric dryness tracking
Description: The system responds quickly to humidity drops by increasing irrigation.
short rationale: Tight coupling to humidity drops; operational responsiveness.

Inference: Weather-driven reductions that correlate with rising humidity indicate precise detection of atmospheric moisture abundance
Description: Irrigation pauses as humidity increases, reflecting reduced drying power.
short rationale: Coupled to humidity rises; operational responsiveness.

Inference: Weather-based reductions occurring shortly before humidity spikes suggest predictive detection of incoming rainfall
Description: The system cuts irrigation before humidity rises, likely anticipating rain.
short rationale: Pre-humidity cuts expose predictive/forecast behavior.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation boosts occurring shortly before humidity drops indicate anticipation of drying conditions
Description: The system may adjust irrigation ahead of atmospheric dryness events.
short rationale: Pre-dryness boosts reveal anticipatory control/behavior.

Inference: Weather-based adjustments that show a strong correlation with temperature changes imply temperature-weighted weather logic
Description: If irrigation adjustments mirror temperature swings, thermal cues shape decision-making.
short rationale: Temp-weighted control; operational insight, low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based adjustments that align more strongly with humidity changes imply humidity-weighted weather logic
Description: Humidity becomes the primary environmental indicator for irrigation needs.
short rationale: Humidity-weighted control; operational insight, low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based increases during cooler periods suggest the system prioritizes humidity or forecast data over temperature
Description: Cold air alone does not prevent irrigation boosts if other weather signals demand it.
short rationale: Humidity/forecast priority over temp; operational weighting only.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during warm, dry periods suggest rainfall input overpowering dryness cues
Description: Even with heat and dryness, rainfall or forecasted precipitation triggers reduced irrigation.
short rationale: Rainfall input overrides dry cues; operational logic only.

Inference: Absence of weather-based increases during very low humidity indicates restrictive trigger thresholds
Description: Humidity alone may not be sufficient to activate irrigation increases unless other factors confirm dryness.
short rationale: Restrictive thresholds exposed; configuration/behavior insight.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during low humidity and moderate temperatures indicate mistaken rainfall detection or sensor noise
Description: Dry air and mild conditions do not justify reductions unless rainfall was incorrectly perceived.
short rationale: Reductions in dry/mild conditions imply misdetection/noise; operational exposure.

Inference: High frequency of weather-based adjustments with stable temperature and humidity indicates forecast-heavy system behavior
Description: Environmental readings remain steady while weather logs trigger changes, implying forecast integration.
short rationale: Many changes without measured swings reveal forecast-driven control.

Inference: Low frequency of weather-based adjustments despite volatile temperature and humidity suggests weak environmental integration
Description: The irrigation logic may rely more on fixed schedules than dynamic environmental conditions.
short rationale: Few changes despite volatility expose reliance on schedules/static config.

Inference: Weather-based increases triggering larger changes during hotter periods indicate combined heat–weather amplification
Description: Temperature and weather signals compound to raise irrigation demand significantly.
short rationale: Amplified response in heat; operational adaptation only.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during extremely hot and humid periods indicate tropical rainfall patterns
Description: These conditions typically involve heavy rain despite high atmospheric moisture and heat.
short rationale: Tropical-like rain conditions; operational/climate signal.

Inference: Weather-system reductions corresponding with sudden humidity surges indicate strong responsiveness to incoming rainfall fronts
Description: Humidity spikes often precede rainfall, prompting early irrigation cuts.
short rationale: Responsive cuts to humidity surges; operational pattern only.

Inference: Weather-system increases corresponding with sudden humidity drops indicate responsiveness to atmospheric drying fronts
Description: Humidity declines signal drying air masses, triggering irrigation boosts.
short rationale: Responsive boosts to humidity drops; operational pattern only.

Inference: Increasing temperature volatility paired with high frequency of weather-based changes suggests a period of unstable weather
Description: Rapid shifts in both systems indicate dynamic and unpredictable climate conditions.
short rationale: Unstable weather drives frequent changes; operational context.

Inference: Stable temperatures with high weather-based reduction frequency indicate consistent rainfall despite static climate conditions
Description: Rainfall drives irrigation decisions even when ambient temperature lacks variability.
short rationale: Frequent cuts with stable temps show consistent rain; operational signal.

Inference: Stable humidity with high weather-based increase frequency suggests temperature-driven irrigation need
Description: Temperature variations—not humidity—are pushing irrigation decisions.
short rationale: High increases with steady humidity point to temperature-driven control; low privacy risk.
